articles.title: Ex-Georgia prosecutor on trial for hindering Ahmaud Arbery's murder investigation
articles.description: Former district attorney Jackie Johnson is accused of interfering with the police investigation into the shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery, nearly five years after he was murdered while jogging.
articles.author: Debbie Elliott

images.alt_text: Former District Attorney Jackie Johnson speaks at the Glynn County Courthouse in Brunswick, Ga. last month. She goes on trial Monday for interfering with the police investigation into the shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery, the Black jogger chased and killed by three white men in February 2020. No arrests were made until months later, and only after video of the crime came out.

articles.title: PHOTOS: President Trump attends several balls to close out Inauguration Day

articles.title: The Wars Trump Inherits
articles.description:
As President Trump takes office he inherits two international conflicts in which the United States is deeply involved. On the campaign trail he said he would be able to end the war between Russia and Ukraine. Last month he said there would be "hell to pay" if Hamas and Israel did not reach a ceasefire and hostage release deal before he assumed office. A temporary and fragile ceasefire began on Sunday.

We hear from NPR correspondents in Israel, Russia and Ukraine to hear about those countries' expectations for the Trump presidency.
articles.author: Greg Myre

articles.title: Austin Tice's mother returns to Syria in search for son
articles.description: For the first time in a decade, Debra Tice, the mother of missing American journalist, Austin Tice, returns to Syria to find news of her son.
articles.author: Emily Feng

images.alt_text: Debra Tice, mother of missing American journalist Austin Tice, speaks a press conference in Damascus, Syria on Jan. 20, 2025.

articles.title: Prince Harry's case against Rupert Murdoch's British tabloids goes to trial
articles.description: A trial begins Tuesday over complaints filed by Prince Harry and a senior British lawmaker against Rupert Murdoch's tabloid newspapers. The trial carries high stakes on both sides of the Atlantic.
articles.author: David Folkenflik

images.alt_text: Prince Harry is suing Rupert Murdoch

articles.title: How do people in war zones feel as Trump takes office?
articles.description: President-elect Trump has promised to end two foreign conflicts. NPR correspondents in Israel, Russia and Ukraine asked people about their hopes and fears as Trump takes office.
articles.author: Joanna Kakissis

articles.title: At least 80 people killed in northeast Colombia as peace talks fail, official says
articles.description: Officials said the attacks happened in the Catatumbo region near the border with Venezuela, following the government's failed attempts to hold peace talks with the National Liberation Army.
articles.author: The Associated Press

images.alt_text: People displaced by violence in towns across the Catatumbo region, where rebels of the National Liberation Army, or ELN, have been clashing with former members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, arrive for shelter at a soccer stadium in Cúcuta, Colombia, on Sunday.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators against the first Trump administration

articles.title: PHOTOS: What we saw on Inauguration Day
articles.description: On the day of President Donald Trump's second inauguration, thousands of supporters gathered in Washington, D.C. Take a look at what our photographers captured.

images.alt_text: A young Donald Trump supporter dresses up as the president on Monday, Jan. 20, 2025, — the day of his second inauguration — in Washington D.C.

articles.title: Trump offers long-promised pardons to some 1,500 January 6 rioters
articles.description: On the campaign trail, Trump regularly featured the stories of Jan. 6 defendants he labeled "hostages" and "patriots."
articles.author: Carrie Johnson

images.alt_text: Pro-Trump supporters storm the U.S. Capitol following a rally with then-President Donald Trump on January 6, 2021 in Washington, D.C.

articles.title: Trump revokes Biden's order for federal agencies to promote voter registration
articles.description: President Trump has reversed an executive order by former President Joe Biden that calls for federal agencies to promote voter registration.
articles.author: Hansi Lo Wang

images.alt_text: A sign for voter registration stands in Columbia, S.C., in 2024.

articles.title: Trump is back and ready to change America
articles.description:
Donald Trump returns to Washington newly empowered.

The Republican party has remade itself in his image. The Supreme Court has granted him sweeping immunity for his official actions. And, unlike last time, he narrowly won the popular vote.

And Trump is prepared to exercise his new power almost immediately. He's pledged to sign an unprecedented wave of executive actions – many of which will be challenged in court.

These actions include one making it U.S. policy to recognize only two biologically distinct sexes – male and female. And his administration would end birthright citizenship — a right explicitly protected by the Constitution.

President Donald Trump's executive actions could make fundamental changes to some of the foundations of American government.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

images.alt_text: Donald Trump is sworn in as the 47th president of the United States by Chief Justice John Roberts.

articles.title: Add to cart: Greenland
articles.description:
President Donald Trump's proposal that the United States take "ownership" of Greenland has raised a lot of eyebrows. Can the U.S. just buy itself this big territory? Is that a thing? Turns out if you look at U.S. history, it's absolutely a thing.

Today on the show: how massive land deals called "sovereignty purchases" have shaped the country we live in today, and why the idea of the U.S. buying Greenland is a lot more complicated than it would have been in the past.

For sponsor-free episodes of The Indicator from Planet Money, subscribe to Planet Money+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Fact-checking by Sierra Juarez. Music by Drop Electric. Find us: TikTok, Instagram, Facebook, Newsletter.
articles.author: Adrian Ma

images.alt_text: Houses on Ilulissat, one of the main tourist destinations in Greenland

articles.description: The president-elect said he will issue an executive order Monday to delay the ban while he brokers a sale. The app has returned on web and mobile, but is not available in Apple and Google's stores.

articles.title: TikTok is offline in the U.S. after Supreme Court upholds ban
articles.description: The app had more than 170 million monthly users in the U.S. The black-out is the result of a law forcing the service offline unless it sheds its ties to ByteDance, its China-based parent company.

images.alt_text: The TikTok logo is screened on a mobile phone with U.S. flag in the background for illustration photo in Krakow, Poland, on Jan. 17.

articles.title: The science behind the FDA ban on food dye Red No. 3
articles.description:
On Wednesday, the Food and Drug Administration announced it is banning the dye called Red No. 3, a food dye additive in many processed foods, like sodas, sweets and snacks. Recently, it and other dyes were linked to behavior issues in children. But high levels of Red No. 3 were linked to cancer in rats decades ago. So why is the ban happening now?

Senior editor and science desk correspondent Maria Godoy answers our questions about Red No. 3 and other dyes that may replace it. Plus, how should parents think about feeding their kids products that may contain Red No. 3 before the ban takes affect.

Questions, story ideas or want us to dig into another food science issue? Email us at shortwave@npr.org — we'd love to hear from you!

Listen to every episode of Short Wave sponsor-free and support our work at NPR by signing up for Short Wave+ at plus.npr.org/shortwave.
articles.author: Maria Godoy

images.alt_text: A bright red drink with a lemon and a stainless steel straw. The petroleum-based dye known as Red No. 3 is found in candy, snacks, and juice beverages, among other food and drink.

articles.title: Cleaning up after the LA wildfires is dangerous. Here's how to protect yourself

articles.title: Is the air quality index actually useful right now?

images.alt_text: Some gas lines were still burning in Altadena, California, after the Eaton fire passed through a burned neighborhood. Crews were working to cut off gas to the area. Smoke and ash from the LA-area fires blanketed the region. Experts suggest care while cleaning up, even far from the immediate burn zones.

articles.title: Why are people smearing beef fat on their face?
articles.description:
"New Year, New Me" Episode 3: beef tallow & natural skincare

According to Pew Research Center, 79% of New Year's resolutions are about one thing: health. It's Been a Minute is kicking off 2025 with a little series called "new year, new me." We're getting into some of the big questions and cultural confusion around our health and wellness.

For our final installment, we're getting into a new skincare trend: using beef tallow as a moisturizer. That's right – beef fat rendered from suet is one of the trends du jour. Brittany Luse sits down with Marie Claire senior beauty editor Samantha Holender and beauty journalist Jennifer Sullivan to understand why the beef tallow trend has taken off, what it says about what we value in our skin care, and whether we should be using beef tallow at all.

Support public media and receive ad-free listening & bonus. Join NPR+ today.
articles.author: Brittany Luse

images.alt_text: Is beef fat good skincare?

articles.title: Many doctors don't discuss sex after cancer. But survivors wish they would

articles.title: Beyond Red Dye No. 3: Here's what parents should know about food colorings
articles.description: Food companies have two years to get Red Dye No. 3 out of their products. But other synthetic dyes have also raised concerns, because of behavioral issues in kids. Here's what parents need to consider.
articles.author: Maria Godoy

images.alt_text: The Center for Science in the Public Interest wants warning labels on food products containing six synthetic dyes.

articles.title: In 'The Brutalist,' art and commerce are always at odds
articles.description:
The new movie The Brutalist is earning a lot of Oscar buzz. Adrien Brody plays a fictional Hungarian architect who settles in America after his family is torn apart during World War II. It's a three-and-a-half-hour epic with much to say about assimilation, wealth, and the creative process.

Follow Pop Culture Happy Hour on Letterboxd at letterboxd.com/nprpopculture
articles.author: Stephen Thompson

images.alt_text: Adrien Brody in The Brutalist.

articles.title: A stranger taught a woman a lesson about being accepting when he helped her daughter
articles.description: On this week's "My Unsung Hero" from Hidden Brain: A little more than 20 years ago, Virginia Squire and her then 8-year-old daughter were traveling in England. Then something unexpected happened.

articles.title: Snoop Dogg and others face heat for performing at Trump's pre-inauguration ball
articles.description: The rapper Snoop Dogg has been taking criticism for performing at one of President Trump's pre-inauguration events over the weekend.
articles.author: Andrew Limbong

images.alt_text: Snoop Dogg performs onstage during Recording Academy Honors in February 2023.

articles.title: How a stranger's kindness taught a mom to be a 'more accepting person'
articles.description: After Virginia Squier's young daughter accidentally boarded a train without her, a stranger stepped in to help.
articles.author: Autumn Barnes

images.alt_text: Virginia Squier (left) and her daughter, Chambers.

articles.title: Village People founder says everybody can enjoy their music, Republican or Democrat
articles.description: Victor Willis of the Village People says their music is for everyone, defending the group's choice to perform at Trump's inaugural celebrations as a message of inclusivity.
articles.author: Majd Al-Waheidi

images.alt_text: Victor Willis of Village People performs on stage at PNE Amphitheatre on September 2, 2018 in Vancouver, Canada.

articles.title: Why are people smearing beef fat on their face?
articles.description:
"New Year, New Me" Episode 3: beef tallow & natural skincare

According to Pew Research Center, 79% of New Year's resolutions are about one thing: health. It's Been a Minute is kicking off 2025 with a little series called "new year, new me." We're getting into some of the big questions and cultural confusion around our health and wellness.

For our final installment, we're getting into a new skincare trend: using beef tallow as a moisturizer. That's right – beef fat rendered from suet is one of the trends du jour. Brittany Luse sits down with Marie Claire senior beauty editor Samantha Holender and beauty journalist Jennifer Sullivan to understand why the beef tallow trend has taken off, what it says about what we value in our skin care, and whether we should be using beef tallow at all.

Support public media and receive ad-free listening & bonus. Join NPR+ today.
articles.author: Brittany Luse

images.alt_text: Is beef fat good skincare?

articles.title: Sunday Puzzle: Name game with initials
articles.description: NPR's Ayesha Rascoe plays the puzzle with Weekend Edition puzzle master Will Shortz and Susie Woodward of Sherwood, Ore.
articles.author: Will Shortz

images.alt_text: Sunday Puzzle

articles.title: On National Popcorn Day, we look back at how they became a movie theater staple
articles.description: Sunday, January 19, is national popcorn day. A century ago, the ultimate movie snack was actually banned from theaters. A saleswoman in Kansas City Missouri helped create a new movie tradition.
articles.author: Mackenzie Martin

articles.title: Meet the artists who set out to show a different side of the US-Mexico border
articles.description: The US-Mexico border is often depicted as a place of destitute migrants, razor wire, and men with guns. A new spoken word and music project in Texas aims to challenge that portrayal.
articles.author: Eric Westervelt

articles.title: With TikTok's future uncertain, creators ponder life without the app
articles.description: Barring a last minute sale by its Chinese parent company, TikTok could soon go dark in the U.S. Now, creators on the Chinese-owned platform pay tribute to it — and talk about what's next.
articles.author: Chloe Veltman

images.alt_text: A content creator on TikTok holds a protest sign outside the Supreme Court building on Jan. 10 in Washington, D.C.

articles.title: Eric Dezenhall discusses link between organized crime and our presidents in new book
articles.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with author Eric Dezenhall about "Wiseguys and the White House," a new book on the interplay between organized crime and our presidents.
articles.author: Steve Inskeep

articles.title: One longtime Gaiman fan on where we go from here
articles.description: Pop culture critic Glen Weldon says he can't separate the art from the artist. But in light of the sexual abuse allegations against Gaiman, he will separate himself from the author's future work.
articles.author: Glen Weldon

images.alt_text: Author Neil Gaiman at an event for Audible celebrating The Sandman: Act III in 2022.

articles.title: Major authors hope new AI licensing site will help them keep control of their books
articles.description: In the wake of several lawsuits involving authors suing AI companies for allegedly scraping their literary works to train models, some big-name writers are signing on to a new AI licensing platform.
articles.author: Chloe Veltman

images.alt_text: A screenshot of the "Created by Humans" website.

articles.title: Newly discovered poems show Virginia Woolf as a fun aunt
articles.description: A researcher — who was looking for something else — stumbled onto two poems by Virginia Woolf. The silly, punny, quickly drafted poems were written for her niece and nephew sometime after March 1927.
articles.author: Andrew Limbong

images.alt_text: Previously unknown poems show Woolf as a fun aunt. She

articles.title: Colson Whitehead shares the true story of abuse and injustice behind 'Nickel Boys'
articles.description: Whitehead's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, now a feature film, is based on a notorious Florida reform school where boys were beaten and sexually abused. Originally broadcast July 16, 2019.
articles.author: Dave Davies

articles.title: The history and evolution of comedy with writer Jesse David Fox
articles.description: Vulture senior editor and writer Jesse David Fox joins us to talk about Comedy Book. It's a book about the history and evolution of comedy through covers and interviews of greats like Jerry Seinfeld, Ali Wong, and Adam Sandler.

images.alt_text: Comedy Book by Jesse David Fox

articles.title: A woman invented the rape kit. So why was a man given credit for it?
articles.description: Rape kits were widely known as "Vitullo Kits" after a Chicago police sergeant. But a new book tells the story of Marty Goddard, a community activist who worked with runaway teenagers in the 1970s.
articles.author: Tonya Mosley

images.alt_text: A sexual assault evidence collection kit is checked in by a forensic analyst for testing in the biology lab at the Houston Forensic Science Center in 2015.

articles.title: Years ago, writer Pico Iyer lost everything in a wildfire. This is what he learned
articles.description: After a 1990 wildfire destroyed his home and possessions, Iyer started over. The loss led him to a Benedictine monastery, where he found comfort and compassion in solitude. His new memoir is Aflame.
articles.author: Terry Gross

images.alt_text: In The Half Known Life, Pico Iyer traveled around the world to discover what different cultures and religions perceive as paradise. His new memoir is Aflame: Learning from Silence.

articles.title: Why laughing while crying is so Korean
articles.description: Comedian Youngmi Mayer talks about how her Korean family uses humor as a tool for survival. She gets into the Korean comedic tradition and why the saddest stuff is what makes them laugh the hardest.
articles.author: Schuyler Swenson

images.alt_text: Youngmi Mayer poses next to her new book, <em>I

articles.title: Show up to your next book club meeting with these 12 reading recommendations
articles.description: Sometimes you finish a book and just have to talk about it with someone else. If your book club is looking for its next conversation-sparking title we have a dozen for you!
articles.author: Dhanika Pineda

images.alt_text: undefined

articles.title: Bilal: Tiny Desk Concert
articles.description: After logging stellar Tiny Desk performances supporting The Roots and Common, this solo set proves the wait worthwhile.
articles.author: Nikki Birch

images.alt_text: Bilal performs a Tiny Desk concert at NPR Music in Washington, D.C.

articles.title: 2025's most-anticipated albums
articles.description:
We highlight some of the most anticipated albums of the year, including upcoming ones from Perfume Genius, Lucy Dacus, serpentwithfeet and more.

Featured artists and songs:
1. Perfume Genius: "It's A Mirror," from Glory (March 28)
2. Florist: "Have Heaven," from Jellywish (April 4)
3. Lucy Dacus: "Ankles," from Forever Is A Feeling (March 28)
4. serpentwithfeet: "Writhing In The Wind," from GRIP Sequel (Feb. 28)
5. Squid: "Building 650," from Cowards (Feb. 7)
6. Jason Isbell: "Bury Me," from Foxes in the Snow (March 7)
7. Saya Gray: "Shell (Of A Man)," from SAYA (Feb. 21)
8. Marshall Allen: "African Sunset," from New Dawn (Feb. 14)
9. Samia: "Bovine Excision," from Bloodless (April 25)

See the complete list of 2025 releases we're tracking.

Enjoy the show? Share it with a friend and leave us a review on Apple or wherever you listen to podcasts.

Questions, comments, suggestions or feedback of any kind always welcome: allsongs@npr.org

Hear the songs in the All Songs Considered playlists in Apple Music and Spotify.
articles.author: Robin Hilton

images.alt_text: Perfume Genius

articles.title: Denzel Curry
articles.description: Rapper Denzel Curry was born and raised in Miami, but his music doesn't really sound like he's from Miami. With his reputation as a Soundcloud rapper – his home isn't so much the neighborhood he grew up in as the website where he posts his music. He joins us to talk about his latest record King of the Mischievous South and his time growing up in Miami. We also get into some of his hobbies – he's a big fan of the card game Magic The Gathering.

images.alt_text: Denzel Curry at the Maximum Fun Studios in Los Angeles, CA.

articles.title: Trump offers long-promised pardons to some 1,500 January 6 rioters
articles.description: On the campaign trail, Trump regularly featured the stories of Jan. 6 defendants he labeled "hostages" and "patriots."
articles.author: Carrie Johnson

images.alt_text: Pro-Trump supporters storm the U.S. Capitol following a rally with then-President Donald Trump on January 6, 2021 in Washington, D.C.

articles.title: The musical universe of David Lynch
articles.description: From Twin Peaks to his films to his own recording career, the director understood how much sound mattered — not only to the audience, but to the characters in his stories.
articles.author: Hazel Cills

images.alt_text: David Lynch at his studio in 2005. The director, whose death at 78 was announced Thursday, made musical curation and interpretation a pivotal part of his storytelling.

articles.title: Billie Eilish, Lady Gaga, Lil Baby and more will play FireAid benefit concert in LA
articles.description: The Jan. 30 event will stream live and raise money for those impacted by the wildfires.
articles.author: Isabella Gomez Sarmiento

images.alt_text: Dave Matthews (from left), Joni Mitchell and Billie Eilish are just some of the musicians performing at the Jan. 30 FireAid benefit concert in Los Angeles in support of those impacted by the Southern California wildfires.

articles.title: Billy Strings on his latest album, 'Highway Prayers'
articles.description: The guitarist and singer-songwriter delves further into his bluegrass roots on his major-label studio debut.
articles.author: Stephen Kallao

images.alt_text: Billy Strings

articles.title: Can James McVinnie change your mind about the pipe organ?
articles.description: On his new album, the British keyboardist offers both engaging and entertaining contemporary works for the misunderstood instrument.
articles.author: Tom Huizenga

images.alt_text: On his new album, Dreamcatcher, James McVinnie offers a fresh take on the venerable, and often misunderstood, pipe organ.

articles.title: 'Forces of Nature' showcases the potent mix of two jazz giants
articles.description: A new recording features pianist McCoy Tyner and saxophonist Joe Henderson in a concert taped in New York City in 1966. The music here is a prelude to later iconic records by each leader.
articles.author: Martin Johnson

articles.title: The Red Clay Strays: Tiny Desk Concert
articles.description: It wasn't a given that the Strays could rein in the grandeur that its fanbase relishes to fit the modest Tiny Desk, but this set proves why it's one of the fastest-rising ensembles in any genre right now.
articles.author: Ann Powers

images.alt_text: Red Clay Strays perform a Tiny Desk concert.

articles.title: In 'The Brutalist,' art and commerce are always at odds
articles.description:
The new movie The Brutalist is earning a lot of Oscar buzz. Adrien Brody plays a fictional Hungarian architect who settles in America after his family is torn apart during World War II. It's a three-and-a-half-hour epic with much to say about assimilation, wealth, and the creative process.

Follow Pop Culture Happy Hour on Letterboxd at letterboxd.com/nprpopculture
articles.author: Stephen Thompson

images.alt_text: Adrien Brody in The Brutalist.

articles.title: Unpacking Hollywood's biopic obsession
articles.author: Scott Detrow

articles.title: Justin Baldoni has sued Blake Lively, Ryan Reynolds for $400 million
articles.description: Baldoni, his studio Wayfarer, and their publicists are alleging civil extortion, defamation and a slew of contract-related claims about the film It Ends With Us.
articles.author: Isabella Gomez Sarmiento

images.alt_text: Blake Lively at a London screening of the film It Ends With Us in August, left; Justin Baldoni, center, and Ryan Reynolds, right, in separate photos at the premiere of the film in New York.

articles.title: Film offers 'Hard Truths' about why some people are happy — and others are miserable
articles.description: Marianne Jean-Baptiste gives a phenomenal performance as a profoundly unhappy woman. There isn't a lot of plot, but director Mike Leigh builds his stories from the details and detritus of daily life.
articles.author: Justin Chang

images.alt_text: Marianne Jean-Baptiste, left, and Michele Austin play sisters in Hard Truths.

articles.title: 'Wolf Man' is toothless
articles.description:
Everything old is new again, it seems, and there's no reason that wouldn't apply to werewolves. We now have a chance to enjoy a new Wolf Man starring Christopher Abbott and Julia Garner. Directed by Leigh Whannell (The Invisible Man), it maintains that sometimes the monster is inside you all along. Plus, we take a minute to remember director David Lynch.

Follow Pop Culture Happy Hour on Letterboxd at letterboxd.com/nprpopculture
articles.author: Linda Holmes

images.alt_text: Christopher Abbott in Wolf Man.

articles.title: Shakespeare meets gaming in 'Grand Theft Hamlet'
articles.description: During pandemic lockdowns, two actors decided to try to stage a Shakespeare play entirely inside the game Grand Theft Auto. Grand Theft Hamlet tells the story.
articles.author: Bob Mondello

articles.title: David Lynch, who directed off-kilter classics, dies at 78
articles.description: His sinister, surreal vision of America made him a leading counterculture auteur — with movies such as Blue Velvet, Wild at Heart and Mulholland Drive, and the groundbreaking TV series Twin Peaks.
articles.author: Kyle Norris

images.alt_text: Director David Lynch has died at the age of 78. He

articles.title: Bid on the bard: Auction features historic items from Bob Dylan's life
articles.description: The lot includes about 50 items and features early handwritten drafts for Dylan's hit "Mr. Tambourine Man" as well as photographs, posters and a signed harmonica.
articles.author: Manuela López Restrepo

images.alt_text: Bob Dylan at a press conference in London in 1966.

articles.title: Oscar nominations are delayed again as fires burn on in Los Angeles
articles.description: Oscar nominations had already been delayed once due to the fires raging in Los Angeles. The ceremony itself remains scheduled for early March.
articles.author: Mandalit del Barco

images.alt_text: The Academy has extended the voting period and pushed the nominations announcements to Jan. 23 as fires continue to burn in Los Angeles.

articles.title: As fires in Los Angeles rage, an already-hurting Hollywood presses pause
articles.description: The fires around Los Angeles arrived just as Hollywood's awards season kicked off. It's an ominous sign at a time when film and TV production is already down.
articles.author: Mandalit del Barco

images.alt_text: A firefighting helicopter flies above the Hollywood sign on Wednesday, Jan. 8.

articles.title: Ohio State defeats Notre Dame 34-23 in college football championship game
articles.description: Ohio State dominated most of the night, and all through the playoffs
articles.author: The Associated Press

images.alt_text: Ohio State celebrates after their win against Notre Dame in the College Football Playoff national championship game on Monday in Atlanta.

articles.title: Latest on NFL Playoffs
articles.description: The NFL conference championships are set after a dramatic playoff weekend. Kansas City Chiefs will take on the Buffalo Bills while the Washington Commanders will play the Philadelphia Eagles.
articles.author: Becky Sullivan

articles.title: What to know about Ohio State, Notre Dame and college football's championship game
articles.description: That the Buckeyes and the Fighting Irish, two of the sport's most storied teams, are squaring off in the title game is a TV executive's dream — and a fitting end to the first-ever 12-team playoff.
articles.author: Becky Sullivan

images.alt_text: The game-clinching play of Ohio State

articles.title: OSU and Notre Dame face off in first national championship in expanded playoff format
articles.description: College football will get a new national champion tonight. Notre Dame takes on The Ohio State University in the first expanded playoffs of college's top division.
articles.author: Becky Sullivan

articles.title: Notre Dame and Ohio State to compete in college football final
articles.description: Notre Dame and Ohio State University are set to tangle Monday in the college football national championship game. The expanded playoffs have led to some surprising results leading up to this unexpected final.
articles.author: Becky Sullivan

articles.title: Marching bands are ready to take the field at the college football championship
articles.description: The college football national championship between Ohio State and Notre Dame on Monday brings students into the spotlight, including the two marching bands that will perform during halftime.

articles.title: Saturday Sports: NFL playoffs, college football, remembering Bob Uecker
articles.description: NPR's Scott Simon talks to Michele Steele of ESPN about the NFL playoffs, the college football national championship, and remembers Milwaukee Baseball legend Bob Uecker.
articles.author: Scott Simon

articles.title: What Netflix's WWE deal means for the future of live sports TV
articles.description: World Wrestling Entertainment flagship live show, Monday Night Raw, moved to Netflix. What does this deal tell us about the fight between streamers and cable companies for the future of live sports?
articles.author: Adrian Ma

articles.title: Why Australian Open live streams look like Wii tennis — and what it means for sports
articles.description: The Australian Open's animated tennis livestreams are making a splash. U.S. leagues have used similar technology to put Simpsons on the football field and superheroes on ice skates.
articles.author: Rachel Treisman

images.alt_text: The Australian Open

articles.title: 'Mr. Baseball' Bob Uecker, Brewers announcer and 'Major League' actor, dies at 90
articles.description: Uecker was the voice of his hometown team who after a short playing career earned the moniker "Mr. Baseball" and honors from the Hall of Fame.
articles.author: The Associated Press

images.alt_text: Milwaukee Brewers radio announcer Bob Uecker tips his cap before a baseball game between the Brewers and the Miami Marlins on July 28, 2024, in Milwaukee.
